content: The "Medicare+Choice Program Improvement Act of 2000" includes provisions such as increasing the national per capita growth percentage, raising the minimum payment amount, allowing a 50:50 blend in 2002, and implementing a 10-year phase-in of risk adjustment based on data from all settings. Additionally, there is a delay in the deadline for offering and withdrawing Medicare+Choice plans for 2001. The "Medicare+Choice Program Improvement Act of 2000" includes amendments to increase the national per capita growth percentage in 2001 and 2002, as well as raising the minimum payment amount. The "Medicare+Choice Program Improvement Act of 2000" includes amendments to increase the minimum payment amount to $500 for 2002 in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Additionally, the act allows for a 50:50 percent blend in 2002. The "Medicare+Choice Program Improvement Act of 2000" allows for a 50:50 percent blend in 2002 for Medicare+Choice organizations. The Medicare+Choice Program Improvement Act of 2000 allows for a 50:50 percent blend in 2002 for Medicare+Choice organizations. Section 1853(c)(1)(C)(ii) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust Medicare+Choice capitation rates for certain payment areas during 2002-2005. The amendments made by subsection (a) do not affect the payment of a first time bonus under section 1853(i) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 6. Permitting higher negotiated rates in certain Medicare+Choice payment areas below national average. Section 1853(c)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow Medicare+Choice organizations to negotiate higher rates with the Secretary in areas where the capitation rate would be lower than the United States per capita cost. This change applies starting from 2001. The capitation rate increase is based on audited data and cannot exceed the projected United States per capita cost. The maximum rate of increase is tied to the inflation rate in private health. The capitation rate increase is determined by audited data and cannot surpass the projected US per capita cost, with a maximum increase linked to private health inflation rates. Adjustments are made for demographic characteristics and to exclude prescription drug costs. Adjustments for over or under projections are also considered for subsequent years. The Secretary must complete negotiations with a Medicare+Choice organization within 90 days of entering negotiations. SEC. 7 amends the Social Security Act to phase in risk adjustment based on data from all settings over a 10-year period starting in 2004. SEC. 8 delays the deadline for offering and withdrawing Medicare+Choice plans for 2001 from July to November 2000. The deadline for Medicare+Choice organizations to withdraw or submit information for offering plans in 2001 is extended from July 1, 2000, to November 1, 2000. Organizations can rescind withdrawal notices before November 1, 2000.
